data.title: Wells Fargo & Company
data.meta_description: News about Wells Fargo & Company, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Inflation Weighs on Nation’s Largest Banks

JPMorgan and Wells Fargo reported that overall deposits dropped. At Citi, losses piled up from credit.

By Rob Copeland and Stacy Cowley

Tripped Up

Help! A Gas Station Charged Me $1,500 and My Bank Won’t Believe It’s Fraud.

After returning home from a wedding in Mexico, a traveler found a huge charge on his credit card and suspected a gas station attendant was responsible. Wells Fargo didn’t believe him.

By Seth Kugel

Edward E. Crutchfield, 82, Dies; Banker’s Deals Reshaped the Industry

He built a small Southern bank into a regional powerhouse, helping to turn Charlotte, N.C., into a national financial hub.

By Stacy Cowley

Biggest U.S. Banks Earn Billions, Even After Insurance Bill

JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported healthy quarterly profits. Citigroup said its ongoing restructuring would result in about 20,000 job cuts.

By Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley

your money: Shuttered Accounts

The Way Big Banks Shut Down Customer Accounts Is Callous. Let’s Fix It.

When banks close checking and credit-card accounts because of “suspicious activity,” chaos and anxiety ensue. It doesn’t have to be this way.

By Ron Lieber

A C.E.O. Who Resigned in Scandal Now Wants More Money

Timothy J. Sloan was criticized for failing to clean up Wells Fargo’s troubled culture when he headed the bank. He says in a suit that he’s owed at least an additional $34 million.

By Rob Copeland

shuttered accounts

Sex Workers Have Been Shunned by Banks, Even When Their Work Is Legal

Financial service companies often avoid what they deem high-risk industries like adult entertainment. When workers lose their accounts, they are left with few options.

By Tara Siegel Bernard

Dimon Warns of ‘Most Dangerous Time’ as Banks Report Big Profits

JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Citigroup said that consumers continued to borrow and spend, but their chiefs warned that geopolitical risks were intensifying.

By Rob Copeland, Stacy Cowley and Emily Flitter

Former Wells Fargo Executive Avoids Prison in Sham Accounts Scandal

Prosecutors had sought a year of incarceration, which they said would be a deterrent to other corporate executives.

By Stacy Cowley
